variant.question: In the ICAO Standard Atmosphere the decrease in temperature with height below 11 km is...

Which describes the intensity of icing, if any, at FL180 in the vicinity of the CANARY ISLANDS (29° N 015° W)?
You are flying with an outside air temperature of -12 °C and a TAS of 250 kt at FL150 through overcast NS clouds. What type and degree of icing is most probable?

options.text: In clouds pushed up against the mountains, moderate to severe mixed ice.
Over flat terrain, moderate hoar frost.
In clouds pushed up against the mountains, moderate to severe rime ice.
Over flat terrain, away from fronts, moderate to severe mixed ice.

variant.question: You are flying with an outside air temperature of -12 °C and a TAS of 250 kts at FL150 through overcast NS clouds. What type and degree of icing is most probable?

options.text: In clouds pushed up against the mountains, moderate to severe mixed ice.
Over flat terrain, away from fronts, moderate to severe mixed ice.
Over flat terrain, moderate hoar frost.
In clouds pushed up against the mountains, moderate to severe rime ice.

variant.question: You are flying with an outside air temperature of -12°C and a TAS of 250 kts at FL150 through overcast NS clouds. What type and degree of icing is most probable?

options.text: In clouds pushed up against the mountains, moderate to severe mixed ice.
In clouds pushed up against the mountains, moderate to severe rime ice.
Over flat terrain, moderate hoar frost.
Over flat terrain, away from fronts, moderate to severe mixed ice.

variant.question: What intensity and type of aircraft icing is likely to occur at FL 100 in a thunderstorm, with the freezing level at 7000 ft?

options.text: Moderate to severe icing due to clear ice.
Moderate to severe icing due to rime ice.
Light icing due to clear ice.
Light icing due to rime ice.

variant.question: The most dangerous icing conditions are encountered in

options.text: zones where the air temperature is below -15 °C.

variant.question: Which of the following is a potential hazard associated with the assessment of ice accretion by a pilot?

options.text: With hoar frost the aerodynamic contour of the aerofoil appears to be unchanged.
Rime ice covers the fuselage on all sides, preventing detection.
Clear ice accretes mainly on the trailing edges of aircraft parts.
During flight, mixed ice is invisible on white surfaces.

variant.question: Given a 0ºC isotherm layer at FL60 and NS at FL70, what is the lowest FL with severe icing hazard?

At what degree of icing should ICAO`s "Change of course and/or altitude desirable" recommendation be followed?
During the en-route phase of your flight you encounter severe icing. According to the ICAO recommendations, you should:

options.text: continue on course with minimum possible flight control deflections.

variant.question: An aircraft in flight experiences airframe icing which makes a change of heading and/or altitude desirable. Which intensity of ice accretion is present according to ICAO terms?
At what degree of icing can ICAO`s No change of course and altitude necessary recommendation be followed?

What degree of aircraft icing is determined by the following ICAO description?

"Conditions in which immediate change of heading and/or altitude is considered essential"
A dangerous mistake which can be made while checking icing during the flight would be:

options.text: Hoar frost can appear to not affect the aerodynamic shape of the wing.
Informing ATC about the icing conditions mentioning the levels between icing conditions were experienced.
Descending to a different flight level where icing conditions are not suspected.
Ice protection systems are selected ON.

variant.question: At what degree of icing (ICAO) should an aircraft change course and/or altitude immediately instruction be followed?
A hazard of icing by freezing rain on the aerofoil of an aircraft is...

options.text: Potential accretion of ice aft of the ice protection equipment.
Formation of a very thin layer of icing mixed with rain that can remain unnoticed.
Ailerons freezing at the outer ends of the wind.

A pilot is warned of severe icing at certain flight levels by information supplied in:

YSCB AD WRNG 1 VALID 161500/162230ZFROST EXPECTED AT THE AERODROME DURING THE VALIDITY PERIOD. THE MINIMUM TEMPERATURE IS EXPECTED TO BE MINUS THREE DEGREEES.
This message is (1) __ providing information about (2) __.

options.text: 1. a NOTAM; 2. closure of the aerodrome.

During the preparation for approach to Zurich airport (1 416 ft/AMSL) a pilot hears the following message on the ATIS: "Inversion warning. Inversion of 12°C between 1 900 ft and 2 300 ft altitude." This message indicates that the pilot should be prepared:

options.text: for wind shear just above the inversion.
that the performance of the engine will be reduced from inversion level down to ground.
for freezing precipitation below the inversion.
